column4: I'm working with an NTFS partition. I've unmounted it, changed some files around, and mounted it again. However, the file I deleted still shows up! How do i force a refresh?
the ubuntu NTFS driver is read only... are you playing with something experimental?
No. I -unmounted- it and deleted the file with Windows. However when i mount again the file is still there! It's not actually reading the stupid drive b/c I've definately deleted that file..
you rebooted into windows, deleted it, rebooted back into ubuntu, and it is still there?
No, I'm using VMware to access the drive natively. I'm sure rebooting would do the trick, but I'm hoping there's a way to refresh the drive...
are you sure you have vmware configured to allow writes to the partition?  it's probably just faking it with copy on write
vmware does allow writes, but it maybe be caching or something, b/c in linux I can still actually play the file (it's a movie) so it's not there. I'll reboot vmware.
you did shutdown the windows vmware session before mounting the partition again right?
No I didn't. Probably not a great idea, but since linux is ro I didn't think it would matter.
hrm ok vmware is down, but the file -still- shows up when I mount it. I guess I can copy all the files I want to a different folder.
start vmware back up and see if it's there in windows... after unmounting it of course
if it is, then vmware is configured to not actually allow writes to the device
ok I'll check
I can't say for certain that's not happening, but the disk file on my linux partition is quite small
if all you did was delete a file it would be.... windows wouldn't write much to do that
you should not have a seperate disk file if you want the vm to actually write to the disk
that seperate disk file is where vmware reroutes writes to instead of the real disk
I don't see how that's possible. I've installed Office 2003 using vmware and the disk file is only 112kb
Plus, that file isn't there on reboot...
That is, the file doesn't show up in windows. it's still there in LInux :/
oops I take it back. after rebooting the vm the file is now gone for linux. Not sure why that was the procses I had to use, but I'll remember it I guess...
nothing
